GHOW nest with 2 young visible. Total nest count doesn't include owl nest.
This colony has grown every year since I started monitoring.

No birds or nests present.
The nest seemed old and partial. No heron, 2 loons, 2 mallards, beaver lodge, very high water, many blowdowns. Trail person said money and help coming to fix the trail.

This was an initial site visit to assess access and familiarize with area. I spoke to several local homeowners none of which was familiar with the site. Identified best way to access wetland areas to the north. Remote site with difficult access.
three nest sites observed
only 2 nest sites observed
No feathers, egg shells etc under nests, lots of crow activity.
A lot of damage to the trees this winter. Only 1 heron nest active now.
No sign of heron. NO water in bog.
No nests seen.
2 inactive nests were from last year, pretty shabby and unkept.

This is my first observation from on the water in a kayak by the bridge. Note that in 2014 there were 6 nests in trees to the left of the bridge going north right on the north side of the river. I only observed 2 nests. There was no activity.
Changed card in camera Nest #1 w/adult cml 688
Chicks in nest #2 seemed closer to 6 weeks. Chicks in nest #4 seemed closer to 4 weeks. The chick in nest #3 was obscured by [txt unreadable] (partially), it never stood completely up

Four adults were sitting low in nest apparently incubating. One adult was standing on a branch of tree #1 and this snag had two active nests. Tree #2 had one nest with incubating adult. Tree #3 also had one nest with incubating adult.

I think there is a second nest present on the right, near shore when facing the active nest. There were 2 adults constantly flying back and forth on that side of the lake. I would be happy to check it out, but suspect that would cross posted land.

Appears that the nest which ultimately failed last season has been re-activated! There are now 4 birds incubating, in the same four locations as last year.

One bird was consistently sitting on the nest, the other bird was perched in another snag nearby.
Four nests from last year were gone as of March this year (and the trees that held them) - looked as though the trees blew down this past winter.
